sentences: Taylor Mac (born August 24, 1973) is an American actor, playwright, performance artist, director, producer, and singer-songwriter active mainly in New York City.
In 2017, Mac was the recipient of a "Genius Grant" from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.
Mac was a finalist for the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for Drama.
Mac moved to New York in 1994 to study at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.
After graduation, Mac began working as an actor and wrote the plays The Hot Month (1999), The Levee (2000), and The Face of Liberalism (2003).
After graduation, Mac began working as an actor and wrote the plays The Hot Month (1999), The Levee (2000), and The Face of Liberalism (2003).

In 2014, for Mac's performance in the Foundry Theater's production of Bertolt Brecht's Good Person of Szechwan, Mac was nominated for the Lucille Lortel Outstanding Lead Actor Award and the Drama League Distinguished Performance Award.
Mac also starred in Classic Stage Company's A Midsummer Night's Dream.
during the Republican National Convention in 2004.

Since at least 2012, Mac and musical director/arranger Matt Ray developed A 24-Decade History of Popular Music, a performance that covers music popular in the United States from 1776 to the 2016, with one hour dedicated to each decade with a corresponding costume designed by long-time collaborator Machine Dazzle.

This work culminated in a 24-hour performance on October 8–9, 2016 with one hour dedicated to each decade.

In 2017, the performance was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize for Drama.
It appeared fifth on a list by The Guardian writers of the best theatrical works since 2000.
On October 29, 2018, in the run-up to the 2018 midterm elections, Taylor Mac performed a cover of Patti Smith's 'People Have the Power' after appearing as guest on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert.

In 2019, Mac's first Broadway play, Gary, A Sequel to Titus Andronicus, premiered April 11 starring Nathan Lane in the title role.
In 2019, Mac's first Broadway play, Gary, A Sequel to Titus Andronicus, premiered April 11 starring Nathan Lane in the title role.
The black comedy closed in June 2019 after both praising and panning reviews.

Mornings – a play about a man's attempt to perform his morning masturbation ritual.

Originally written for the performance art play "Cardiac Arrest or venus on a Half-Clam" Now included in The Be(A)st of Taylor Mac.
The Dying Sentimentalist – commissioned by Arena Stage and premiered there in 2014 as a part of the "Our War" monologue collection about the Civil War.
The Hot Month – produced by Boomerang Theatre Company in 2003 on Center Stage.

The Lily's Revenge – Created as part of HARP and premiered in the fall of 2009.

Presented by La MaMa E.T.C. in association with the Talking Band in 2011.
The Young Ladies Of – Based on letters written to Taylor's father after he placed an ad asking young ladies to write to him while he was stationed in Vietnam in 1968.
The Young Ladies Of – Based on letters written to Taylor's father after he placed an ad asking young ladies to write to him while he was stationed in Vietnam in 1968.
Thousands replied to this ad.
Premiered at FEZ and subsequently headlined the Queer at HERE festival in 2004.
The Be(A)st of Taylor Mac – premiered at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2006 (produced by Paul Lucas) where it won a Herald Angel Award and performed in various venues in New York City.
Mac's Dionysia Festival: four plays that are being premiered separately but will someday be premiered in an all day festival mirrored after the Greek Dionysia.

Hir – a play about a dysfunctional family including a mad housewife, a transgender child, a son that spent three years in combat in Afghanistan, and a husband who had a stroke that left him nearly speechless.
Produced by Playwrights Horizons in November 2015.
Recognized among The New York Times top ten list for Best Theater of 2015.

Part IV: Gary: A Sequel to Titus Andronicus – Set during the fall of the Roman Empire (400 CE), the years of bloody battles are over, the country has been stolen by madmen, and there are casualties everywhere.
